results.title: Aussie Rules Footy
results.brief_description: Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

constellations_primary.name: A world of firsts
constellations_primary.description: There’s a first time for everything. In their own way, these films, television and videogames each broke ground.

results.description:
Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.
description_for_label:
Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.

results.title: Auguste and Louis Lumière
results.brief_description: In 1895 Auguste and Louis Lumière patented the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity, but its biggest achievement was projection.

constellations_primary.name: The Lumière brothers
constellations_primary.description: The Lumière brothers understood the potential of cinema to be exhibited theatrically. Only one person could watch films through Thomas Edison's Kinetograph, while Auguste and Louis exhibited their films to thousands with Cinematographe.

results.description:
After learning about Thomas Edison’s Kinetograph in the early 1890s, Auguste and Louis Lumière set out to free motion pictures from Edison’s bulky contraption. In 1895 they succeeded, patenting the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity. But its biggest achievement was projection: while only one person could look through the Kinetograph’s peephole at a time, audiences could watch Cinématographe films together.

Alongside their invention, the Lumière brothers premiered 10 short films on daily life, known as actualités, including the famous Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat (1896). The Cinématographe even inspired the new art form’s name: cinema.
description_for_label:
After learning about Thomas Edison’s Kinetograph in the early 1890s, Auguste and Louis Lumière set out to free motion pictures from Edison’s bulky contraption. In 1895 they succeeded, patenting the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity. But its biggest achievement was projection: while only one person could look through the Kinetograph’s peephole at a time, audiences could watch Cinématographe films together.

Alongside their invention, the Lumière brothers premiered 10 short films on daily life, known as actualités, including the famous Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat (1896). The Cinématographe even inspired the new art form’s name: cinema.

results.title: Anamorphic drawings
results.brief_description: Anamorphic illusions like these hide their true subjects in distorted perspectives. When you view them with a viewing cylinder they reveal recognisable images, and some are even made to unveil their images when you look from the right vantage point.

constellations_primary.name: Power and infamy
constellations_primary.description: Beginning with an anamorphic image of Napoleon III, this Constellation focuses on representations of the distorted perspective of patriarchal power.

results.description: Anamorphic illusions like these hide their true subjects in distorted perspectives. When you view them with a viewing cylinder they reveal recognisable images, and some are even made to unveil their images when you look from the right vantage point. Anamorphic drawings helped establish perspective in paintings, photography and special effects, and they also influenced the development of CinemaScope and widescreen in film.
description_for_label: Anamorphic illusions like these hide their true subjects in distorted perspectives. When you view them with a viewing cylinder they reveal recognisable images, and some are even made to unveil their images when you look from the right vantage point. Anamorphic drawings helped establish perspective in paintings, photography and special effects, and they also influenced the development of CinemaScope and widescreen in film.

results.title: Alice Guy-Blaché
results.brief_description: Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio. She made hundreds of films between during her career, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux

constellations_primary.name: Lost and found
constellations_primary.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

results.description:
Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio, Solax. She made hundreds of films between 1896 and the 1920s, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux (The Cabbage Fairy, 1896).

Guy-Blaché later experimented with early synchronised sound, colour and special effects, often filming on location with hundreds of extras. In 1912 she made A Fool and His Money, widely believed to be the first film to have an all–African American cast.

To find our more about Alice Guy-Blaché, rent Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché on our streaming platform, Cinema 3.
description_for_label:
Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio, Solax. She made hundreds of films between 1896 and the 1920s, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux (The Cabbage Fairy, 1896).

Guy-Blaché later experimented with early synchronised sound, colour and special effects, often filming on location with hundreds of extras. In 1912 she made A Fool and His Money, widely believed to be the first film to have an all–African American cast.
